bagno-nettuno.it
/en/

We were just there yesterday. We just rented 2 lounge chairs with shades by the water. I didn't even get the name but I did take pictures of 2 spots. Here are the names....maybe you can find them online

What you call a rental company, we call it "bagno" (pronunced like the spanish baño) or "lido". You can rent a beach umbrella with 2 sunbeds ("ombrellone con 2 lettini") or a fully equipped cabana ("gazebo" most likely) . Be aware that the word "cabina" has got nothing to do with cabana: it means a small private changing room.

comments.comment_text: I would go directly to Rome and get a hotel there. There are so many important sights to see in Rome - be sure to buy tickets in advance online for the Vatican, et. If you stay in another city, you may not get back to Rome in time to catch your cruise due to the notorious train/plane strikes in the summer months.

That’s a choice you will need to make. We have done both. We have flown into Venice. Loved Venice and the canals and then train to Rome. If you want to see the Vatican and Colisseum you can do that with 2 full days in Rome. If this is a one time
Trip I would fly into Venice. Spend 2 nights. Add an extra night in Rome and see the
Sites over 2 days. Then cab trip the port in the the morning.

We have done Mediterranean cruises to both directions starting Civitavecchia. We flew into Roma and spent 3 nights before heading to Civitavecchia. It’s about 1.5 hour ride from Roma Termini. If you are coming all the way from Venezia to Civitavecchia, add at least another 4 hours on high speed train on top of it.
I would just fly into Rome a few days before, and fully enjoy the city, and then go out to the port for your cruise

Your first Day you going to be exhausted. So make it relaxing and then spend the next two days, really doing all of the great sites In rome, and then you can go on your cruise. Others may tell you to take a day trip. I wouldn't or you'll just be more exhausted for your cruise. Enjoy rome it's one of the most fascinating cities in the world

fast & cheap… although need to consider luggage.

If you’re a hiker and love nature, it’s a must! Not sure of heat and crowds in June.

You gotta visit places and do activities which speak to you. Many will have differing opinions. Best to ask “why and why not”.

If you Travel early June, then it’s ok, no crowds (it’s not Amalfi, Rome, etc). I’ve been there even in the middle of august and still good.

June is perfect!

I go every year.if you need any help give me.a.shout.
I was there in late April of this year! All the spring flowers were in bloom! Temperatures were in the mid to upper 60°'s in higher elevations and low 70°'s around Merano and Bolzano.

Well I lived in the Alps for 16p years, weather can be unpredictable, often storms in afternoon. Alpine meadows at their best, beautiful verdant green,p still snow high up, can still be chilly especially in evenings.
June hands down. You likely to have around 4 hours daylight more than in September

text:
Just discovered this group, love how helpful everyone seems to be. Thought I’d share a relatively unknown event that is truly unique and I can’t recommend enough.
Carnival, the days leading up to the Lenten season, is celebrated across Italy with each city having its own traditions. In the smaller town of Ivrea in Piemonte, Carnival means the Battles of The Oranges. A tradition set around the tale of a tyrant baron in the 13th century, he declared his right to jus primae noctis on the miller’s daughter, the Mugnaia. Once taken to the castle, however, the Mugnaia beheaded the baron and set off a revolt of the townspeople against the baron’s men.
Today, for 3 days the townspeople, divided up into 9 groups of Aranceri (basically krewes for those familiar with Mardi Gras), battle “the baron’s men” who parade through the town in horse-drawn carts. The weapons for the battle: oranges. There’s a ton of other tradition and ceremony involved but I won’t make the post longer explaining it all, but highly recommend for a truly once in a lifetime experience.

As for logistics, Ivrea is an hour north of Turin by direct train. Naturally places to stay in town sell out far in advance, I stayed in Turin and just took the train each day. Ivrea itself is a beautiful town with history as a city going back to ancient Rome, though you’ll want to go before the madness of the celebrations to enjoy the city and its sites. Turin is also rather underrated so it was nice staying there and seeing what it has to offer, and another easily reached by train destination from there is Genoa, one of the most architecturally beautiful cities I’ve ever seen.

comments.comment_text: Thanks for sharing that it looks fabulous! I think I'm going to start researching before I decide on dates to travel I would love to see traditional customs

text:
Days 15-18 of my 3 week solo trip: Cinque Terre!

Cinque Terre was hands down my absolute favorite part of my trip but it started horribly.

If you remember my last post about Florence, you might recall my cell phone service completely crapped out on me. My poor mom back at home in NJ was trying to talk to verizon at all hours of the day and night to try to get them to fix the issues. We thought we had it solved... but it wasn't until I was on the train to La Spezia that I realized it wasn't fixed, my phone had only been working because of wifi. So I got to cinque terre still without service. I got to the airbnb (more on that in a second) and basically stayed there for SIX HOURS on the phone with verizon because if I left, I wouldn't have wifi and thus no way to talk to them. Eventually the representative told me there was nothing else they could do for me and that they'd elevate it to the next department... which would get back to me in 10-15 days 😑

I may or may not have told the lady if I end up on the back of a milk carton, it would be her conscious.

ANYWHO.... 😅

From La Spezia, getting the train to Cinque Terre was super easy. You can buy they train/trail pass online and avoid the line at the station.

I prearranged with my airbnb host they he would meet me at the train station and he did. He walked me to the airbnb which was relatively easy to find (Riomaggiore by the marina). When we got there a lady from a unit above mine came up to me. She and her husband only spoke English and they couldn't get their stove to work... and the instructions were only in Italian. My airbnb host only spoke minimal English so as a group we all went up to their unit and I played translator between everyone (thank you duolingo) and eventually we figured out the stove situation.

The airbnb had a stunning view. It was perfect for just me. It COULD host six people (bunk beds) but I think it would be a little crammed.

During my days in cinque terre, I spent time in each town. I think Riomaggiore was the perfect place for me to stay but I also enjoyed really Manarola. I spent one of my afternoons there swimming and jumping off the rocks.

I also did the pesto making class at Nessun Dorma. It's the only food class I did during my trip because I kind of have it in my head that cooking classes are more fun with a plus 1. With that said, this was a great class. Very fun. I was a little bitter that everyone else got to trade off with their partners/group when it came time to beating the basil leaves... whereas I had to do it the whole time (it's exhausting lol). But the experience was definitely worth it. The owner has so much personality. We got to chatting about my trip and he ended up gifting me a free t-shirt.

I also did a sunset boat tour... which I was lowkey disappointed in. The people on the tour were all very nice and friendly. But the guide assured me that swimming would be a big part of it and that I should run back up to my airbnb to change into a bathing suit (I arrived in a dress, but the meeting point was just outside my airbnb). I changed, we set off... and it was like pulling teeth to get anyone to swim. And it was basically a quick dip before we got back on the boat. Also I don't have many pictures from the boat because I had to leave my phone tucked away to avoid it getting wet. Everyone who had to sit at the front of the boat got drenched from the waves. Would I do another sunset tour? Yeah probably, but I'd consider a different company.

I didn't get a chance to do the hiking trails becuase I didn't have enough room to pack the appropriate footwear. (Just another excuse to go back and visit again!)

Oh and one last personal note from this trip, at one point I stopped in a restaurant while they were setting up to ask a quick question. I got to talking to a waiter and he was super kind. Fast forward several hours later and I walked past the restaurant and all of a sudden I hear "Kristen Amore!" I looked around and the waiter had called out (causing multiple people to look at him and thus me) and held up heart hands 😅 it was very cute. We never hung out though cause I was leaving the next day.

I'm probably missing a lot of things. Cliffnotes: good pesto, fun water activities, gorgeous views, would definitely return.

text:
Planning on visiting the Dolomites to hike in early June next year, but I’ve seen 2 completely different opinions on Google. Some say to avoid it at that time while others say it’s beautiful then.
Wondering what any of you think! Thanks in advance!

comments.comment_text: At the beginning of June it may be more rainy than in full summer...

I spent a summer there as a nanny in a small town called Predazzo, a province of Trento. I didn’t do much hiking because I was with small children, but I did visit the neighboring small towns, such as Cavalese, and took the funivia up the mountains where the temperatures were much cooler and the nature was spectacular.
We love visiting the mountains in June. That said, if there is a late snowfall like this year, some higher trails and lifts may still be closed. Still better than the crowds in July and August.

My sister is there now
Staying in San Cassiano
There is a little bit of rain and fog in the mountains so far
But it’s beautiful apparently :)
I hiked Dolomites on sept.2021. Been to other hikes and till now its the most beautiful hike I've done.. I highly recommend it.
We were just there the second week of June and it was beautiful. We stayed in Silva Val De Gardina.
We went up May 24-26. We stayed in Lajen and hiked alpe di siusi. It was definitely a little early, but still so amazing and I’d do it again. First or second week of June should be nice!
The alpine meadows are best in June. High up you may find snow patches still. And alway aim to be back in the valley by mid-afternoon as afternoon storm are common in June.

We live in the Dolomites and early June its beautiful. But because its not tourist season yet the mountain huts are still closed and so are some restaurants etc. But if you like quiet and beautiful...
Dipende dall'anno,può piovere molto a inizio giugno e quindi ci può essere parecchio freddo e ancora neve in giro. Solo una questione di fortuna.

text:
Morning from Sydney Australia 🇦🇺
Initial planning any feedback would be welcome 🤗.
June 2024

Arrive in Split x 4 days
Split to Athens x 4 days
Athens to Naxos x 4 days
Naxos to Santorini 4-5 days
Santorini to Bari x 2 days
Cosenza to Tropea x 6 days
Tropea to Rome x 3 days
Home 🏡

Will be arriving in Rome around 12 noon. Planning to head to Naples the next day via train and take the bus from there to Sorrento. We're staying just overnight in Rome to rest from our long flight and hopefully just see a bit of the sights in the afternoon assuming we can be in the city by 3 or 4 pm after going through customs, getting ourआणखी luggages and taking the train into the city. Which area/neighborhood would be best for us to stay overnight in, somewhere that makes it easy to get to the train station early morning, as well as get a feel for Rome when we arrive in the afternoon? We're going back there at the end of the trip for 5 days so it's not important for us to hit major sights the day we land. We're not trying to see all of the city in one afternoon just to be clear. Just need a place to relax in a bit after the long travel, and have a good dinner. Maybe have a nice late afternoon or night time stroll.

comments.comment_text: Stay in the Piazza Navona, Pantheon area. It is central and close to the Trevi Fountain. Very walkable and not far from the Rome Termini train station.

Just stay next to the train Station. You can see Santa Maria Maggiore Basilica and then walk down via Nazionale, have an icecream and reach Colosseo and Via dei Fori Imperiali in 20 minutes. Then everything is really close in the city center (Fontana di Trevi, Pantheon, Piazza Navona ...).
Aventino Hill (metro circo massimo). Check aventino group hotels.
Hope you have book your overnight accommodation 🌻

I haven't been to Rome yet, but in your circumstances, in any city, I would look to stay close to the drop-off from the airport and the rail station. Once you've dropped stuff off, will be easier transport-wise to go to and back from a nicer place or a recommended site and food. Minimise time wasted, easy in and out the next day.
Eitch Borromini is a great hotel right behind Piazza Navona.
Stay in the Piazza Navona area - super Rome feeling and absolutely beautiful
Stay beside the train station. That works for the next day too. I did a few train journeys and it worked out well for me.
Reading this sight I'd take a golf cart tour for a few hours

text: Lago di Braies today 😀

comments.comment_text: Vanessa Bryant
Manuela Fernandes

text:
Hello Everyone 🙌
I am planning a trip for June / July next year. There will be my husband, our 2 year old and myself. We have 4-5 weeks It feels like a lot of ground to cover so would like to know what’s worthआणखी seeing and what’s not worth the hype.
I would also love advice on how long to stay in each area and the best form of transport to get around and take in the beauty.

Stops in Italy: Como, Milan, Tuscany, Florence, Amalfi Cost, Sicily (Scopello)

Thank you in advance, I have found the advice on this page valuable 🍝🙏

comments.comment_text: I would trade Milan and Como for Venice. Main cities 3 days each to allow park time as well as art/soaking up the atmosphere. Sicily next time, Spain & France next time (do a Med cruise). Definitely not July August for yourselves but esp child too hot & crotchetty!
Oude centrum pompei en vesuvius, with beach
Monte baldo and lake garda are amazing, not on your list of places but lago di fusine in udine district is amazing
Too hot for this type of extensive trip with a 2 year old .. I have done it and never again .. the stairs alone in Italy are hard to tackle

My best places/ must go’s are -

Beaches between Cap D’Adge and Sete,
Eze (not Eze plage, the village up high in the hills it is spectacular)
Nice old town
Menton - stunning sea side town right next to Italian border
Portofino - is very touristy but stunning
Bellagio and hop on the ferries and town hop in Como, the Hotel Metropole terrace is fabulous for people watching and the buzz of the place
Main square & Duomo in Florence
If you get time you really must go to Siena - it’s very very beautiful, especially Piazza Del Campo
I would also squeeze in a visit to Lago D’Iseo and Lake Garda whilst you are that way. Lake Iseo is far less touristy and Lake Garda is just magnificent.
What an incredible road trip!
Fiona O'Donnell
Sicily alone, if you want to really experience it, will take 2 weeks

In June/July/
August, remember that the whole of the northern hemisphere is on their Summer break. If you must travel then, book things well in advance or you simply will miss out. It’s also very hot, so you will need to take extra care.
Earth Trekkers is a family with their own website and all the information you want . Just take a look !

Did a day tour fron Barcelona to Gerona , Pal and the Caldera and also a day tour ( 3 Countries) to Andorra , Themes , B... something , Wonderful and so easy by bus . Used Tripadvisor a lot ! Barcelona is one of my favourite cities ! When you visit Nice or Monaco , be sure to visit St Paul de Vence , Eze and Antibes . We used ITALY TOURS for small groups , they are excellent excellent especially in Florence and Pisa , Rome and Pompeii.

Italy is a beautiful country but it is incredibly hot and crowded in June and July. Many are now traveling now as traveling was difficult during Covid.

I spent a summer in Italy years ago and again last summer. The crowds this past visit was more than tripled which made it were incredibly difficult to visit museums and get a table in restaurants in a reasonable amount of time. Try to visit smaller towns/villages so you may experience ￼the wonderful hospitality, culture, and foods of this amazing country.

Think about traveling by train if your next stop requires a long drive. We loved traveling by train. You can relax, not worry about stopping for gas, and just enjoy the ride. Remember, when you rent a car there is always the concern of what to do if you have engine problems.

Have the best time of your life!
You've missed of Venice 😳

a pretty hefty endeavor!!! and with a two year old!! mamma mia! looks like you better drive!!
go from St Jean to Lake Como then south to avoid doubling back from Como; i always avoid doubling back

You could consider going from provence to the lakes (Maggiore is very pretty too) and then go cinque terre on the way south in Liguria that part of the region is much prettier than towards France - Portovenere is a nice smaller town in the southern most part of the area and less touristy than the five - doesn’t seem like a big detour from your itinerary - and then go Bologna/
Florence after.
And south of Amalfi visit the old Greek town of paestum and the huge Christ statue in Maratea

I’ve stayed on the Amalfi coast, Rome, Florence, and Assisi. Would go back to any of these places.
If you have time, check out the BLUE GROTTO.
The best period to visit the Italy is from April to July and from September to October. It is less expensive and there aren't many tourists.

Mere Keegan hello as an Italian who lives in Italy I am delighted that you want to visit our country. We Italians (unfortunately)
do not know that we are so lucky. For the trip, I advise you to use the means of transport more in the northern part of the country up to Florence. In southern Italy I recommend the car (the means of transport are not efficient). If your trip is for cultural purposes, I suggest you stop more in the cities of: Milan, Venice, Florence, Rome, Naples (Vesuvius).
If the aim is landscapes and the sea: Liguria (Alassio, Portofino), Lake Como, the Amalfi coast, Puglia (Salento) and Sicily.
but as someone has already advised you, I would do Sicily on a next trip, perhaps combining it with a visit to Sardinia (even if the prices are very high).
Enjoy our country more than we do. Sorry for my English.
Buca Mario for dinner in Florence. AMAZING! Florentine beef is to die for. You need a reservation here so have your concierge or someone capable do this for you asap. 👍🏻

Nice, but I think you should really do Naples instead of the Amalficoast. We haven been there last week. Naples is beautiful, i think the Amalficoast is a little bit overrated. I think it is nice to see it, but make a boat trip and then you have seen the most.
I agree. 1 day in milan
If you're going up North, the Dolomites are absolutely incredible.
In Sicily you must see Taormina and San Vito

A mi modo de ver. Florencia necesita dos días . Como y Lago Magiore tres días, sobretodo por ver Isola Bella. La Toscana lo que tú quieras, es mucho por ver y Milán dos o tres días. En la costa Amalfitana y Sicilia no he estado pero hay mucho que ver por lo que tengo entendido. Y te has dejado cinquè Terre, cerca de Milán y vale la pena pasar un par de días
the Veiled Christ in historic center Naples!!
Don’t skip Venice💕

It is a lot, I have been in most of the places ….well you did put a lot of stops..it is nice, but sometimes you need to stay 1-2-3 nights to « discover the place «, plus with a kid it is also a bit different time wise . I definitely recommends to shorter it a bit maybe and focus on what you would like to see & do. Maybe Focus on Italy and do just Barcelona, Cap Ferret..
I would suggest a stop in Turin, Italy. Beautiful city

For como: do seaplane to look at lake como from above ( book beforehand ) and rent a boat for 4 hrs ( get some wine/ pizza on board ) and just explore the lake yourself ( do not need boating license ) .
Wow. We had 2 weeks and only did Puglia and didn’t see everything we wanted. I think you’ll spend a lot of time in the car with this busy schedule.
Thank you for the information
Siennas cool, near Florence. Cinque Terre too touristy and 500euro fines for stopping to take selfish,so much congestion.

What is written is very good.. but exclude Milan, except Duomo and Scala and Galeria there is nothing to see.. exclude Palma in Spain.. stay only in Italy.. Como.. San Remo.. Cinque Terre… Venezia.. Firenze… Roma… Amalfi… Taormina… Etna… Check out on Google my suggest.. this is perfect… if you like at least to change the country.. go to Dubrovnik.. via Ship from your last stop in Sicily… Have fun 🤩👍👌 cheers Alex
Following

Plenty of amazing towns in Tuscany. Siena is my fave 😊. I also love Ortigia/
Siracusa and Taormina in Sicily.
Nicole Aure
F
Considera las altas temperaturas durante ese tiempo.
Hi Mere...I just sent you a friend request. I have both lived in and traveled in Italy and would be happy to give you some suggestions.
When my kids were little (before school age), we tried to travel in the off season.
Da la vuelta a Italia x la nacionales en auto y paras en todas las vistas como hice yo 20 años atrás hasta sicilia

Milan was disappointing. It is able to successfully portray its over the top pretentious charmless image while being overwhelmingly filthy and graffiti-riddle
d. Use it only as a passthrough to the Lake Como area, which is fantastic.

With all the recommendation,
also think that you are traveling in the heat of summer with a 2 yr old.

Don't forget to come and visit Malta and Gozo while in Sicily. In one and a half hour you will be in Malta from Sicily with the catamaran. Come and visit our island in the middle of the Mediterranean. You will sure love it.

We have just come back from 4 weeks in Italy.
We visited Rome, Bologna, Florence, Tuscany (incl surrounding area) Ancona, Trani, Bari, Amalfi, Naples and back to Rome.
We used mixture of car hire and train.
We would definelty do more train travel next time (it was so quick and efficient and less stressful than the car... tolls, parking, petrol punctures!!)
In saying that, car hire lets you explore outlying areas and be more flexible....whi
ch was worth it.
July is soooo hot though and the humidity is very high.
We found this limited what we planned to do each day.
We retreated back to accommodation in the afternoon.
Remember a lot of the streets are cobbled and are steep or have steps...conside
r this for strollers? (And / or suitcases!!)
Some of the villages in Tuscany (with car hire) are stunning and worth a visit (early - parking gets limited) = Sienna, San Gimigano where amongst our favs.
We found Trani a hidden gem (if going east) - stay central - feels more like a greek fishing village 🙂
Amalfi....you dont want to drive here!! (catch buses/trains/
ferries)

Highlights for us Bolonga (great food scene and compact for walking/
exploring) & Trani.
These areas where less crowded in the peak season.

Why that big curve to go to Lago di Como? Go right up throught Piemonte instead.

Not advisable to drive the Amalfi coast in July. Very narrow road, lot of traffic, no parking. Go to Salerno, park there and go by boat to see Amalfi and Positano. Bus or taxi up from Amalfi to Ravello, the most beautiful town, with magic views.

You will probably not want to go that far. Sicily is big, save that for another trip. And
honestly, even without it, this trip is not very suited for a 2 year old....
I would do Rome and skip Milan. Love the smaller areas.
Scopello Is not on the East coast of sicily. And Como Is overrated
I would start the trip in June from Sicily. In July the weather is too hot.
Is this all by car?
Where are you planning to start? Also are you doing a self drive?
Looks like too much territory to cover within your time frame for me, you need 4 to 5 days in each place as a minimum plus a lot of driving you need to do
All Perfect spots.❤️🇮🇹
I live in Le Marche....if you want non touristy, old Italy and people who speak Italian! Hilltop towns, great traditional food and cheap!

Decades ago there was a theory..never less than three nights anywhere. Looking back, it did work. I've been most of the places you're considering. I'd mix it up..a big city, a small place, somewhere longer to sort of get to know, another destination for just long enough for a taste. Maybe do a trial run several months before the trip to see what kind of pacing works with your child. I've used trains on multiple trips in these countries...the
y are often superb.
Massimiliano Carli il turismo
Check out atlas obscura. They have cool things to check out!

We went from Naples to Amalfi then down to Sicily via Tropea which was lovely. We then did the top half of Sicily (Taormina, Aeolian Islands, Trapani, Egadi Islands and Palermo.) It was a great trip, we got around mainly via trains and ferries. We stayed at most places two nights. If I did it again, I would stay 3+ more at most places so it’s not as rushed.
Jace McBride
Following 🙂
first: go in may-june. by july the holidays in most european countries have started and it will be packen. may-june is pre-season
If you want to go in Spain, after the Sicily, don't pass in Liguria. Maybe you stay a week on queue on highways.

This is quite a huge trip.
You won’t be able to stay for more than 2 days one one place.
Last year we did a similar trip from the north (Milano/Como) over the Tuscany to Naples and the Amalfi to the other side (Adria) and all the way down in Puglia to Speccia and back through Italia Umbria/Marken to Getmany. It was a three weeks trip.
Maybe you decide also make sicila and maybe the Golf of Naples and a bit of Liguria would work.

But to make the Cote Azur ‘till Barcelona and to Mallorca, you’ll have been to the probably most beautiful places but without seen them. I would say go twice.

In Europe is much more concentrated, less countryside than f. E. in the USA. It means there is much more to see in hundred km than in the USA, because it’s not so wide.

Best wishes
Don’t miss Verona and try to see a performance at the Arena …. Breathtaking
Thank you for sharing!! Enjoy!
Try to include Sienna in your Tuscany trip.

Hi! I’m from Italy, I’ll probably skip Milan, or just use 1 day for it. Florence absolutely yes and in Tuscany you need to visit val d’orcia or Creste Senesi, which have the typical tuscanian landscapes. In Sicily I would recommend Palermo 1 or 2 days with Mondello and San Vito Lo Capo ❤️ enjoy! 😍
Following!

Trains and ferries unless you really like driving. Driving gives you much more flexibility for spontaneous stops and meals. Have done all, roads are usually very well kept and not too difficult to navigate, except for the big cities or the historic zones where driving is severely restricted but you may find yourself there by accident. Looks like a great route and plenty of time. You can try all transportation options for parts of the trip.
Learn Italian it helps
Keep Sicily for a separate trip especially this time of year with a child .
no need to spend much time in Milano - there is just the square and its beautiful Duomo, the rest is worth. When you are in Florence, if you have time, visit Siena, amazing
F
All I am going to say is do not go in July or August. I just came back from 6 days there and it was so hot I was miserable. I never sweated so much in all my life.

Drove from rome to south of Spain other day😅 heat was mental was meant to stay for a while took 28 hours straight to drive from rome to Alicante in Spain roads are good if you pay for the tolls can be a bit expensive

You have listed some nice locations. Here’s some other recommendations
to consider: Island of Capri and the Blue Grotto are absolutely beautiful. San Gimignano has sone awesome history and fantastic wineries and Cinque terra is incredible as is Venice! Enjoy, it’s my favorite vacation destination! 👍🏻
June, July and August the worst time to be in Italy specially with a baby. Very hot and packed with tourists

If its your first time in Italy you can’t skip Rome imho, i would skip Sicily and do the stops in Italy like this (since you’re coming from France)
2 days (1 night) Ligurian coast
1 day Milan
1 day Como
2 days Florence
4 Days Rome (there is a lot to see)
3 days Amalfi coast
Palio in sienna . Visit Lucca . you will love it there.
Make sure you apply for a visa before travel.
You are travelling with 2y. Less is better.

We did 3 weeks once in October and it rained for at least 7 to 8 days. During that trip we hit every popular area by flying into Milan 1 day caught a train to Venice and had a hotel (Doge Palace) for 2 days then rented a car and traveled everywhere ending up leaving out of Rome. We did not have any hotel reservations just drove until it started to get dark then looked for a clean Albergo (motel) and they were always clean and very reasonable in price. We did not do the autostrata (freeway since you had to pay every time you get on and off and I video taped our entire trip and rail was in the way to get good pics). We went through little town and villages and really got to see the countryside. The second time we went first week of May before tourist season and got the best rates for our places to stay. We flew into Rome and went to Puglia region, spent about 10 days in Tuscany and Umbria region. We even stayed in 2 villas in the wine country and partied with the locals when the gio de Italia (bicycle racing) was going on. Our very favorite place was Sorrento which is fairly close to Amalfi Coast and ended up staying there for 2.5 days. You can do Pompei, Capri also. You are on the ocean but you dont pay the high costs of Italian Riviera area. Cinque Terra area was also beautiful. Siena on the way to Tuscany. We did not do the typical tourist restaurants which was so much fun trying to communicate and order off the menu. They did not speak English. The food there is the greatest and I dont eat cheese (formagio). The best trips we have ever been on. It was a little scarry when my husband had to drive in the big cities such as Rome, Milan, Genoa. Assisi was beautiful. Scarry driving around Perugia.
Richard Clark
Following

Dont make what i call the „american mistake“ and miss out the very best region. South Piedmont/
Langhe Region. Barolo Wine, Truffels. UNESCO world heritage. One of the most beautiful regions in Europe.

The Galleria dell’Accademia – or Accademia Gallery – in Florence, Italy, is without a doubt most famous for its sculptures by the great Renaissance artist, Michelangelo. His Prisoners (or Slaves), his St. Matthew and, above all, the magnificent statue of David within the Tribune… don’t miss it!
Following
Lake Iseo!
Following
San Gimignano and Volterra, very nice places
Following
Alberobello, The Amalfi Coast, Florence, Bolzano and everything in between. As far as how many days in each place, I'd play it by ear, especially with a 2 yrs old

If you skip Rome when heading from Tuscany to Amalfi coast you should have a go to Abruzzo...
It's one hour drive from Rome, eastbound (the two highways you see on the map) and you will be nicely surprised: three National Parks in the region, beautiful nature, wild landscapes and great food!
Places to see? Day 1 Rocca Calascio, Gran Sasso National Park, Campo Imperatore, and then day 2 you can have a try to Abruzzo, Lazio and Molise National Park and drive through Anversa, Gole del Sagittario, Scanno Lake, Pescasseroli, Barrea, Altipiano delle Cinque Miglia, Sulmona...
Following

Hello, I'm Italian l, living in Sicily. Skip Milan and focus on the other cities as Rome and Florence....but
not too much... As it's boiling in July you may want to go to the beach. Puglia and Sicily are just perfect. Please note that Scopello (which is gorgeous) is not there (not in the middle of Sicily) but on the coast. In Sicily you should go to Taormina and Siracusa at least. ( the island is amazing but it is worth another visit to see Palermo, Catania, Noto, Ragusa...). Feel free to ask whatever you want.
Banalissimo percorso. C'è tanto altro da scoprire in Italia. Ma forse è meglio così, le chicche le teniamo per chi ha voglia di approfondire il nostro stile di vita al di là degli stereotipi.
Following
F
Following

I'm doing a similar trip, arrive Bari Airport head to Alberobello (visit Brindisi, Lecce and Toranto) 4 nights. Leave visit Matera en route to Pertosa caves, stop in Potenza. Continue to Ravello for 4 nights visit (Pompeii, Positano, vesuvius Naples) leave and visit Pastena caves and head towards Cervete for 4 nights (visit Rome) leave and head to Sienna, stopping at Grosseto on the way (night) stay in Sienna 4 nights. Visit San Gimignano, head to Florence (maybe overnight) before going to Rimini for 3 nights (visit minature village, see cave restaurant and gola d furlo) leave Rimini, head to Spello 5 nights (visit Assisi, Cortona and Orvieto) on last day visit Marmore falls on way to airport. The next trip I will do top half (Garda, Sirmione, Verona, Venice, Cinque terre etc)
F

Don.t forget Lago di Garda
SIMPLY beautiful

Just came yesterday back home from our trip to Italy with a toddler (1y and 10m). Even though it was crazy heat wave and busy tourist month, we loved the first trip with our daughter to our favorite country 🥰 I believe it’s matter of your own attitude and taking it on childs pace and needs first. Of course Italians also love children and in many places take them in consideration very nicely (for example food was delivered very quickly for her in restaurants).

We travelled around Emilia-Romagna and Toscana with rental car. This was a must in the heat having the air conditioning! Would recommend Fiesole area about 7km from Firenze up in the hills. Book a nice Agriturismo there and do day-trips to Firenze center and around the beautiful hills. Firenze is really easy to walk with strollers and main attractions are quite near each other. We had an Agriturismo where there was swimming pool and a lot of animals 🐴🪿🐄🐖🫏

We went in July and temps were 95-97 degrees e do keep in mind the heat, but it’s beautiful there so we didn’t mind. Also we walked 8-12 miles a day, lots of steps up and down places.

Florence/
Tuscany areas please stop in San Gimignano it’s a beautiful little city with a beautiful winery. Rome don’t miss the Trastevere area, and please stop in the Umbria region as well. I missed this spot and I guess I’ll just have to go back! Lol. But friends have been and share its loveliness. On the Amalfi coast check out Agricola Fore Porta restaurant. It is a farm to table restaurant with everything homemade. It’s quite a hike to it but so worth it!

Fate una deviazione ed inserite Matera - Taranto - alberobello- Monopoli-Polign
ano- Bari …inoltre continuate fino a Palermo e da lì prendete la nave 🚢 per Cagliari (Sardinia) e fate tappa a Nora, Masua, barumini, bosa, alghero e prendete la 🚢 per Barcellona

As an Italian, i suggest to avoid tourist traps, fine hidden gems like tellaro instead of cinque terre. In Milan, don't miss the Cenacolo (to be booked well in advance) and the amazing museums (Novecento, Brera, scienze naturali), Sant'Ambrogio, the new porta Nuova district. Two days are totally ok. Lake Como is overrated in my opinion, isola bella, lago d'orta and other lakes are less known. However, isola Comacina, tremezzo, Varenna are all nice places to visit. In Toscana, don't miss gems like Pitigliano, Massa Marittima, Pienza. On your way South, you could also plan a stop in the amazing historical sites of Tarquinia and Vulci. Norcia and Castelluccio are amazing places in Umbria. Spoleto and Montefalco are also nice stops, you really have infinite choices. In the South, Matera, Otranto, Lecce are beautiful.
Following!!!

Maybe find accomodation in Lecco instead of Como. The city is on the other branch of the Lake of Como, it is probably cheaper, you can use ferry to Bellagio, Verenna and to the villas on the lake and it has a beautiful scenario as it is in the middle of mountains. You can reach easily few of them like Piani d'Erna where this pic was taken. You can also catch train from Milan to Lecco.
Cinque terre is amazing!!! We just got back and that was everyone favorite spot we went.

Florence/Siena/
San Gimignano
Amazing !! 10 days it will be fine !! May or October !!
Following

Just got back from Italy in June with my 3 year old.
All the small towns were where we had the most fun and relaxation.
They had so much charm and beauty. We could easily get around and we would nap her in the car between places.
We did a couple of big cities and the crowds were not enjoyable with her. Although we got to skip the line a couple of times.
Almafi at that time of year is heaving with people. Also stressful driving.
Como was also very busy!!! We liked Lake Garda better.
Off the beaten path and more beach and nature focused was all around better with a child. And I honestly liked it better!

Untold Italy podcast has lots of tips.

If you are foodies, then you should stop in Parma, Modena and Bologna. I would also recommend traveling in September or October. Fewer people, and better weather. Keep in mind the buildings in Italy are old, so there isn’t A/C available everywhere.
July is too hot ! We have 42 degrees in Rome and 46 in Sicily
Following

Having lived in Italy I would avoid traveling there in late June and definitely would not consider July. Hot is an understatement and it is so crowded everywhere including the autostradas. Try for late April or May. 😊

The only other city I would recommend is Bologna which I think is a very underrated city. My sons & I spent 3 days there. It’s beautiful & very walkable. I also agree with others that Umbria is amazing. Perugia & Assisi are highlights there. It’s hard to choose if it’s your 1st trip.
You can't miss the mountains of Trentino
Visit "Brucoli " in sicily .

We just came back from a 2 week trip and went to Rome, Pompeii, Positano, Amalfi, Capri, Orvieto, Bagnoregio, Montefiascone (my Dad was born there), Tuscany, Florence, Venice. If I had to do it all over again I’d skip Rome and Florence. Florence just had soooo many people and it was hard to walk around. I would do Orvieto again in a heartbeat! text:

text:
Hi! We’re planning a family trip to Italy next year. It’s going to be my husband and I, our two kids aged 6 and 9 and my parents. My dad is in his late 70s but fit. Which cities would you recommend we visit? I’ve already been to Rome, Venice and Florence but don’t mind a repeat with my family. Also, which is a better time to visit.. early April or mid June?

This is the itinerary I’m looking at:
Rome 2 days
Florence 1 day
Venice 1 day
Milan 2 days (day 2: lake Como)

Thoughts? Is this doable or over ambitious?

comments.comment_text:
We just went with a 6 and 9 year old and found Rome to be fun, but mildly overwhelming for the kids. Florence was a nice middle ground in terms of being big, but less attraction-heav
y. They liked the stores, the views, street vendors and walkability. We made sure to get a hotel with a pool for breaks and it was the best decision.

I vote for April since mid June is very hot and super crowded, long line every where. Highly recommend to purchase tickets in advance and pack light (carry on only and a back pack) if you do June. Since you travel with your kids and parents it’s best to slow down and enjoy the surroundings instead of rushing from one tourist spot to another. It seems close distance but still take half a day to travel from place to place, and think about the unthinkable like train rescheduling , or cancellation. Florence and Venice for me have to be 2 days each at least. We spent the day to visit Lake Como stayed in long line to purchase boat tickets to Bellagio then boom the boat was rescheduled to take off 4 hours later so we missed it but did get a refund. If I were you I would save Milan Lake Como for another trip, and combine them with the Dolomite’s which is breathtaking. Just my two cents hope it’s helpful.

text: Has anyone flown TAP Portugal with the Away Bigger Carry on luggage? Away says the size works for TAP requirements in the list of airlines on the Away site…but on the TAP site it doesn’t look like it would.. Iआणखी just wanted to see if anyone has flown TAP with this carry on and, if so, have you had any issues taking this on the flight with this airline?

comments.comment_text: I would stay within the dimensions and weight TAP requires. I saw many folks with carry-on suitcases being asked to check their luggage to see if it didn't fit within their standards or was overweight. However, anyone with a backpack waved on through to the plane.

We just flew on TAP to Rome and back a few weeks ago. We had 21” carry ons for luggage and 1 bookbag each. They weighed every piece: carry ons and book bags. Carry ons were deemed to weigh to much and had to be checked in. So watch not only the size but the weight of the carry on, if you don’t want to check it in.

Just last month I flew TAP from chicago to Lisbon to Rome. And then Milan to Lisbon to Chicago. There was a group of 10 of us in my group and we all had different experiences, but ultimately they made us all check our bags. 3 of us had to check in at the airport where they asked us if we had any bags to check. We said no, we just have our carry-ons and our backpacks. They weighed our bags and checked them all. I was pretty upset because I showed them that same exact screenshot that you posted and the agent said that that was for premium or something like that. He said because it was a screenshot he couldn’t trust it. So I then found it on their website and he said “okay just a minute” then proceeded to check all our bags saying we were all over weight. Luckily he didn’t make us pay so at least there was that. And we were terrified about our luggage getting lost but it didn’t! And we were also worried that we’d have to wait a long time at baggage claim at FCO but that wasn’t the case either. So it ultimately worked out, but we were very worried the whole time. Our friends got to the layover in Lisbon without having to check their bags, but they don’t play around in Lisbon. They measured and weighed every person’s bag as they were getting onto the plane on the jetway. On our way to Rome they didn’t make our friends pay.

On our way home, we got on the plane in milan without having to check our bags. But in Lisbon they got us again. And this time we each had to pay $100.

Hopefully this helps! If you’re not flying out of Lisbon at all, you might have better chances!
We flew ITA Business class and had been worried about size and weight but it seems that on ITA size and weight are irrelevant when flying BC. Good was great and so was the flight LAX to Rome.

We flew TAP from FCO in May and checked 2 large AWAY
suitcases and 1 large AWAY duffle. The checked bags were included in our seat price. We also carried on the small AWAY carryon. We were gone for a month….transatl
antic cruise. Flight went though LIS.
Dareon Carrington

Flew TAP Air Portugal last August. They lost our luggage for 10 of our 14 days. I’m still waiting on compensation.
I’d suggest carry-on only but after reading some comments, that may not be feasible for longer vacations. They need to do better!
TAP is a great airline. You will like it but do everything it says in the instructions about luggage. Otherwise, you will pay a lot of money.

Always go by what the airline states in their rules and screenshot it for your quick reference, then assume you'll be checked. Otherwise, just check a small bag and carry a backpack, avoid the worry. Or pack less.

text:
I cannot thank everyone for their advice. We just got back from a 14 day trip to Rome, Florence, and Venice. Yes, it is hot and humid. We made a personal decision to do private tours as a means of avoiding lines and trains. LivTours was amazing and highly recommend. The guides were careful with the heat and always sought shade. This decision allowed us to do everything we wanted and maintain our sanity!

My recommendations... sneakers during the day and sandals at night. I felt like my feet were cooking in the sweat and heat. Stopping a lot as many other people suggested. We enjoyed beverages and gelato to stay cool and use bathrooms.
Everyone was kind and helpful. Even if people didn't speak English they would find someone who did to help us out. Pickpockets are everywhere. We were a group of 4 and stuck together. I did hear many people saying they either lost their wallets or were pickpocketed. I had the Travelon pocketbook with the locking zippers and my husband had the undershirt neck wallet.
We are already talking about going back since it was an amazing vacation. Thank you everyone for sharing your experiences, it really helped us make our trip perfect!

comments.comment_text: I wish I could go back

Sounds good next time go in May or October, being a tourist in the constant heat is no fun at all

LivTours is excellent!

text: Looking at luggage requirement for carry-on baggage. We are traveling American Airlines from BNA to JFK and the carry-on requirement is 22x14x9. From there we transfer to Alitalia Airlines from JFK to Rome and the Rome to Genoa. It appears the carry-on requirements for Alitalia Airlines is smaller than AA at 18x14x10 and 11 lbs. How strict is this enforced and we will have an issue if the bag is within the AA requirements but over the ITA requirements?

comments.comment_text: For European flying, if it doesn't fit in the pre-boarding sizer, there will be an excess charge.
Please folks...stop asking this question and just adhere to the requirement. One airline doesn't honor another airlines requirements. If you want to take your chances then fine...
Assume it will be enforced and plan accordingly. No one knows in advance. Choose your path.
Are you talking about ITA Airlines? Alitalia no longer exists
Be prepared to pay excess baggage and/or put you your bag in the hold

https://
www.ita-airways.
com/en_gb/
fly-ita/baggage/
hand-baggage.htm
l
European airlines have enforced regulations. Their planes are smaller, their overhead capacities are smaller. The guidelines reflect that.

If it is a carry-on, and you want to keep it as a carry-on and not be forced to check it, you need to go with the smaller size requirement. We had the same situation - different airlines. You need to go with the most strict requirements to be able to keep it as a carry-on. Safe travels!
This was strictly enforced when we were in Italy
European carry on sizes differ from US. It must be the European size or you will have to check it for a fee
Assume it will be enforced. On my last trip in April I saw lots of people having to gate check their carry ons.

I don’t know why people are so offended by this question. It isn’t totally clear whether or not this is a code share flight and code shares often honor the ticketing airlines regulations. You may be correct in this case, but I also think that this might be a very valid question depending upon the circumstances. Everyone is way too quick to jump on the people asking the questions when questions are precisely the reason this group exists.

I just flew from London to Italy to Greece and my carry on baggage was within the size for each airline and becuase the flight was so full, they took my carry on and checked it - no extra fee but it defeats the purpose of carrying the right size. The flights are oversold so they are just doing what they can to get the planes off and running and not worrying about people hauling their luggage onboard

I've found with these carry on requirements and you're slighty over, a LOT depends on the mood of the guy at the gate. If he just won 10 Euros in the lottery, you're probably good. If he just found out his wife is sleeping around, plan on handing over the carry-on.

Is this booked as 1 ticket?
Because AA is not a partner airline of ITA, ITA is not one world partner.
If it was your status with AA (if you have any) would transfer over.
We flew AA then IB and since we have status we’re able to carryon our rollers (mine is 21” including wheels)

If you are on separate tickets you might have to go to the ticket counter at JFK and check in them go back through security.
Not sure if the gate agents will check it for you….that might cost $$$ depending on your class of ticket.

Whichever the case is they have sizers to place it in and you can see if it fits big difference from 22” to 18”… the wheels get caught up etc..
Always check with the airline directly, you can get some bad luggage advice on here

Look at the luggage reqs for all airlines you are flying and adhere to the strictest/
smallest reqs.
Ita weighed our checked luggage, but no one looked at the carryon.

Per ITA website on baggage…carry on suitcase is listed as 21.7” height, 13.8” width and 9.9” depth (all converted from centimeters). Weight limit is 17.6 lbs (8 kg). Personal item is listed as 17.7” x 14.2” x 7.9” with no weight limit.
I bought the bag with the smallest measurements so it would work on any airline
Always go with the smallest and lightest of all the airlines you are using. No problem then.

I wonder if those newer collapsible bags will count as a carry on and fit under the seat?
I’ve never tried one.
On the way there it was no issue, but on the way back I saw several people forced to pay and check their carryon that was not within the guidelines

Alitalia airlines? Tell me you're an old time traveller without actually saying it!😅
https://
www.ita-airways.
com/it_it
It's not a matter of how strict the controls are: it's just that your carry on item will not fit in the overhead lockers!
My experience is that intra European flights are pretty restrictive with luggage size.

text:
Hello,
My husband and I have the opportunity to visit Italy for 7 days (not including travel time) — is this enough or should we look into doing something else? We have two young children and my mom has offered to watch them for 9 days total. This opportunity wouldn’t come up again for awhile, so we were thinking why not just give it a go! Neither of us have ever been before, so maybe just share the must see places or if you’ve done a “quick” trip before! TY 🫶🏼

comments.comment_text: We went for our first time in June. We flew into Naples and stayed in Sorrento for 3 nights with day trips to Capri & Amalfi Coast. Then took the fast train to Rome for 4 nights. Amazing vacation! I would suggest picking one or two home base cities and do day trips based on your interests.
Go. Don’t pass up the opportunity. Don’t try to do too much. Maybe pick one or two places max.
Go! Go! Go! Just Go!

What month of the year are you going? Get a copy of Rick Steves Italy guidebook and start narrowing down the locations. Seven days aren’t enough to see everything, so start from which airport you are arriving/
departing.
Go for it! Just pick 2-3 places and enjoy! You won’t regret it!!

Yes. I would suggest just two destinations, probably Rome (3 days) and the Amalfi Coast (4 days), assuming you will be going from late spring to early fall. That combination will give you a taste of urban sophistication and laid-back dolce vita with sea and sun.
I agree! Pick two cities and concentrate on doing things there and take your time. You will have a great time just don’t go in Summer months

Yes! Definitely go!!! 💚🤍❤️ As someone else has suggested... look up Rick Steve's guidebooks. I would recommend doing a mix of staying in one bigger city, and maybe one smaller town. For example, Florence for 4 or 5 days (can do a day trip to Tuscany, maybe a day trip to Lucca), 2 or 3 days in Cinque Terre. We just stayed in Manarola. Highly recommend! Enjoy your time together!
We just arrived back from 10 nights and 11 days.... Absolutely so much to see and not enough time. Focus on the things that are of interest to you!
Go, but just pick a couple of places to see and enjoy
Venice and Rome OR Rome and Amalfi Coast!
Just go! 🇮🇹❤️🇮🇹

text:
Florence🇮🇹

Our first experience with the train was not as difficult as I had feared. Booking through the Trenitalia app was great because I could see our train number and platform before it was even posted on the board. The business class seats were really comfortable.

It was not to find taxis in Florence for 5. Our hotel said there’s only 4 vans in Florence that can seat over 4 people. We walked about 0.7 miles to hotel. Very hot even though not far. It was 104 degrees Fahrenheit.

We checked in at Arte Boutique hotel. Beautiful boutique hotel and beautiful room. It was the only room we got that fit all 5 of us. We had 2 hotel rooms everywhere else.

We ate at Gozi Firenza near hotel. Very good lunch and service.

We went to central market and wish we would have eaten here just due to the variation of choices. Got some souvenirs, tasted olive oil and balsamic vinegar, cocktails to carry around while shopping, ate a cannoli.

We could walk to Galleria del Accademmia from our hotel. We had tickets bought online prior for 16 euro a person-no tour. Only about a 5 min wait since we were early. Went right in to see the Art and David. We headed back to shower and rest before dinner.

We had dinner at Trattoria Za Za-read many mixed reviews. We booked months in advance. Great service. Great food and wine!

We found a wine window about 5 min walk to Cantina de Pucci. Really fun and unique experience!

We walked to duomo to see some of the shops and had some gelato.

We were only able to stay in Florence for 2 days; we enjoyed it but it was ranked last according to our teens (age 19, 17, and 14)

text:
When you arrived at each city, what was your choice of transportation to get around the city to do some sightseeing? Car, foot, bus, scooter/vespa?... Im terrified of the rental car or Vespa to be stolen when parked...what are your thoughts on that?
What was your choice to do the sightseeing? Thanks in advance.

comments.comment_text: Can you tell us your destinations? Rome's centro storico (historic center) is very walkable. In Venice you can only walk or take a boat. To get to the Amalfi Coast, take the ferry or private transfer from Naples. Once you are there, the ferries are a good choice. The local government has put restrictions on the use of rental cars. There are buses as well. In Florence, you can walk nearly everywhere. From Florence, you can take the train to Siena, Lucca, and Pisa, and train+bus to San Gimigano. Otherwise, the Tuscan countryside is not very well served by public tranport. A car comes in handy. Milan: walk and public transport. Lake Como: take the train there and ride the ferries around the lake. Puglia: a car is necessary to really see things, though the east coast is reasonably well served by train. Sicily: the major towns are served by train, but if you want to see many of the villages inland, you'll need a car. Dolomites: a train will take you to the bigger towns, but to really see anything, a car is necessary.
In Rome it was metro ;) if you are staying in center so walking😉
Taxis are everywhere and are reasonable.

We walked everywhere in Rome, Florence and Sorrento. We averaged around 13 miles a day and loved every minute it. You get to see take it all in while on foot. The only time we used trains was for traveling from one city to another.

E-scooters rentals all the way. No way we could have done everything we did without them.

Riding them through Rome was a bit nuts, though. Street traffic in Rome is insane if you're not used to it.

We walk or take public transportation.
Sometimes a cab.

Everywhere is walkable if you are fit unless you want to go outside the main town - foot and train for us !
I have always relied on public transportation.
I stay beside the train station... Then public transport all the way. Google maps for directions. Easy!!

We walk everywhere, use taxis sometimes. We have had rental cars on some trips - the Amalfi, Puglia, driving up the Adriatic coast, driving from Florence to Rome, but we would leave it parked except when moving locations or in Puglia we did a lot of day trips to neighbouring villages. Never worried about it getting stolen.
Vespas are a bad idea unless you have ridden one a lot in busy city traffic before. Not recommended for getting around the city. Vespa tours in the Tuscan countryside sure maybe, if you are a good calm driver with good spatial ability.
Hop on hop off bus.

text: What can you tell me about flying with Vueling?

Ryanair, on the other hand, is to be avoided at all costs. It felt like some kind of perverse game in which the airline kept figuring out new ways to screw passengers over throughout the entire experience, from booking to picking up bags at the end of a flight. Just awful.

text: My family and I are planning our first trip to Italy next fall. We’d like to start in Florence and do day trips through Siena, San Gimignano and an organic farm before heading to the Amalfi Coast to end our trip. Is ot best to work with a tour package company to plan the itinerary and transportation or are there reasons we should consider planning our tours and transportation independently?

comments.comment_text: You can drive to those areas from Florence. Don't rent a car in downtown Florence. Watch out for the zona limitato - only people with special tags can drive to limit the number of cars, if you do come in to Florence. Our rental company covered us for that but if yours doesn't there's a fine. If you can get one at the train stain and return it there that wouldn't be bad but trying to return a car after dark can be crazy. Add time onto the times that even Rick Steves gives you. It will take longer. It will take some time just to get outside of Florence. Make sure anyone who drives the rental has an international driver's license or a big fine from the police if they stop you for any reason. And don't speed. They have a lot of cameras. Easy driving in the country - a lot of curves but not tons of traffic in October.

You can save a lot of money planning it yourself which is what I did. It is a lot of research but I learned so much more doing it myself and that way you can set your own itinerary too that suits your schedule.
I did everything independently booked flights, booking .com apartments and used the trains , booking them about a month or so in advance - local trains you get while you are there
I’m planing my trip and what has been very useful is Rick Steve’s Italy guide- also I’m watch lots of great Italy guides on utube videos- so much fun!
We used a tour company and never had a worry. It was so nice to have them take care of every small detail. Yes, it cost more but worth every penny to us 👍

We have done that exact trip ourselves approximately twelve times. If you want to give some money to somebody else you can, Or you can use the GPS on your phone. And it'll take you exactly where you want to go. It's so simple that I even I could do it

We used Florence Limousine Service for a winery tour in Chianti (with lunch) and in San Gimignano (with snacks). They were very reasonably priced and the tours were great. One of the highlights of the trip.
It’s kind of fun planning on your own. Check these groups and watch videos of the different towns. You’ll learn a lot.

Plan it yourself, its part of the fun. You will learn so much more. Use trains.
I’ve travelled in Italy many times now, alone and I plan the whole thing myself and rarely join organised tours unless it’s just a day trip that is difficult to do alone, or by train/ bus.
With some research you can do it yourselves and save money. Look at Rick Steves guides and other online resources. That way you can also build the itinerary that you really want.
If you do a lot of research you can do it all yourself, that way you get to know the country & how far each town is. 2 apps that I use all the time is Rome2Rio & Man in seat 61 🌻
For fall traveling, plan it yourself.

As long as you enjoy research, planning and are an organized person, you should absolutely do it yourself! But remember NOT to over plan- allow for some spontaneous time to relax with a glass of wine or shop or explore the neighborhoods ❤️

text:
I cannot thank everyone enough for your help with me planning our amazing trip to the most amazing country ever! I couldn’t have planned the trip without the online groups. I was so glad to visit the country that my grandfather came from when he was 12.

I’m going to break up my posts per city and start with Venice.

We went to London first and flew from London to Venice via British Airways. We all used one small carry on and a backpack.

Day 1 Venice

Pickup by VQ Travels water taxi to hotel which was absolutely amazing! What a great company to work with for travel arrangements! It was the most spectacular entrance to Venice and Italy via a private water taxi.

We checked into All Angelo Art Hotel, but our rooms weren’t ready so we got lunch around the corner at Rossopomodoro. We all got pizza, and it was amazing!

After our lunch we walked around a little and headed back to the hotel, our rooms were ready and we all took naps.

We loved our hotel and rooms. We had a beautiful canal view for each of our rooms. We had 2 rooms for our family of 5.

We went to a little place right around the corner from our hotel for Apertivo and had some snacks and Aperol Spritzes.

We went to dinner at Ai Due Viscovi-it was okay, not our best meal but decent service and good pasta. We walked around and stopped at a few places on our walk back and discovered at the one the amazing Hugo Spritz! Those are amazing.

Day 2 Venice

We went for a Gondola ride after breakfast-just grabbed the one beside our hotel canal 80 Euro for 5 people 30 min. I’m glad we did it since I had heard mixed reviews.

We walked around and got lost in the streets of Venice. We ate chicchetti for lunch no reservation-just walked up. Some of the smaller stores didn’t take credit cards in Venice, so make sure you have Euros. I had read everyone took credit cards here and there and that’s absolutely not true.

We had dinner but I can’t remember the name! We didn’t have a reservation. It was good but service slow.

We walked up to a little restaurant in San Marco for tiramasu. loved the service and staff. Excellent dessert!

We went to our St Mark’s Evening Tour with Walks and Devour tours. Really well done and informative tour!

Then got some drinks at the cafe next to St Mark’s and went to listen to the music in the piazza.

Day 3 Venice

After our hotel breakfast we had our pickup from VQ Travel in water taxi to train to Florence.

We loved All Angelo Art Hotel. Perfect location. Everyone was so kind, clean rooms, amazing breakfast, beautiful view!

Our first experience with the train was not as difficult as I had feared. Booking through the Trenitalia app was great because I could see our train number and platform before it was even posted on the board. The business class seats were really comfortable. I watched a few You Tube videos and read everyone’s posts in here and had no issues.

I will have a separate post for Florence, Capri, and Rome!

Bolzano is a good base- very accessible by train (and bus!) to most of South Tyrol. Most towns have cable cars that will take you up to the nearest mountain. It’s very convenient and you don’t have to worry about parking your car.

Trentino Alto Adige is the Dolomiti region par excellence, but also in Veneto there are beautiful places, like Cadore area and Cortina d’Ampezzo.
It’s not easy to move around on Dolomiti without a car, but you can get to Cadore from Venice, and so you can also visit it!
About the best season to get there, it depends on what you want to do: for skiing of course you need to go in winter/spring (from Christmas to Eastern more or less), for hiking or biking, summer is the best.
Enjoy, Dolomiti are amazing!

Christina Cabrera: I stayed in Ortisei earlier this month and it was beautiful. There are lifts in town that will take you to the top of Seceda (can’t recommend this enough) and alpe di Siusi which we didn’t do. The whole area is stunning! Also check out Cortina d’Ampezzo to use as a base.
Val gardena you can see all real Dolomites beauty..but it depends when?if you like skiing so winter 😉

text:
Tuscany Day Trip from Florence: Siena, San Gimignano, Pisa and Lunch at a Winery
Art, history, countryside, food. Tuscany has it all. If you only have one day free, venture into Tuscany on this day trip from… आणखी Florence and discover the region's highlights with a local guide. Explore the medieval city of Siena and its cathedral before heading to the hills of Chianti for a 3-course Tuscan lunch and wine tasting. Roam the streets of San Gimignano, and travel to Pisa to admire the architectural drama of Cathedral Square—home to the UNESCO-listed Leaning Tower of Pisa. Upgrade to include skip-the-line entry, if you wish.

Read more about Tuscany Day Trip from Florence: Siena, San Gimignano, Pisa and Lunch at a Winery - https://www.viator.com/tours/Florence/Tuscany-Day-Trip-from-Florence-Siena-San-Gimignano-Pisa-and-Lunch-at-a-Winery/d519-5070TUSCANY?pid=P00070587&mcid=42383&medium=link&medium_version=selector
